newsitem.title: MAURITIUS: Africa bourse forum aims to boost investment.
newsitem.headline: Africa bourse forum aims to boost investment.

text.p: Africa's financial markets are still in their infancy and need regional capital markets to boost cross-border investment, Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said on Tuesday.
Reforms would render Africa's financial institutions more efficient, competitive and solvent, Salim told 114 participants at the start of an OAU/African Economic Community (AEC) conference.
Fifty African countries are represented at the 3-day forum aimed at facilitating implementation of the 1994 Abuja (Nigeria) Treaty for an African Economic Community.
"African financial markets are in most cases still in their infancy, fragmented and until the recent reforms heavily depressed," Salim said.
Commercial banks dominate African markets accounting for the bulk of individual African country's consolidated assets, AfreximBank Vice President J.L. Ekra told the forum.
Lack of intra-African capital movement hampers the growth of African financial systems, he said.
"Recent estimates suggest that our continent is able to attract only 4 percent of global capital flows," Ekra said.
Some countries hold $20 billion in reserves with import coverage up to 36 months, while others had virtually nothing.
"Africa's reserve position currently stands at $43 billion, enough to cover some six months of imports," said Ekra.
Forum participants include policy makers, consultants, executives and financial market operatives.
